DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
Eds: Subs 3rd item to CORRECT to hyphenation of Day-Lewis
DOC.TEXT: Actor Daniel Day-Lewis says that confining himself to a wheelchair for the six weeks of filming ``My Left Foot'' was necessary in portraying disabled Irish artist Christy Brown. ``I took the liberty of thinking that it was imperative to do it this way and did not think about any inconvenience I might have caused because, in the end, it was beneficial to show the people on the set what we were trying to do,'' he said. Day-Lewis remained in the wheelchair even during breaks, communicating only with grunts and requiring aides to feed and carry him. Brown, who died in 1981, was written off by doctors as a mental defective but later rose to prominence as a writer and painter. The cerebral palsy victim used his left foot, his only controllable limb. In researching Brown's life, Day-Lewis said he learned that Brown never considered himself handicapped and wanted desperately to be considered normal. ``He has unwillingly become a spokesman for the disabled,'' Day-Lewis said, ``and he probably is the worst person in the world to be a spokesman. He ... had an overwhelming sense of his own disabilities. I don't think he ever came to terms with it.''
